title: [Large-Scale] Modular Engineering Education Course Design: Simulation/VR-Based Practitioner Competency Strengthening and Advanced Scientific Inquiry Methods Application

context.prior_knowledge: Foundational engineering concepts, experience using engineering tools, and basic understanding of the scientific method (hypothesis formulation, variable control, experimental design, data analysis, evidence-based conclusions)
context.additional_context: Customizable modular design for current practitioners, emphasizing learning flexibility and autonomy. Systematically applies scientific inquiry processes for engineering problem-solving in simulation/VR environments. Strengthens practical competencies through a step-by-step approach (observation, measurement, analysis, conclusion), with particular emphasis on variable control in experimental design to ensure scientific rigor.

learning_goals: Learners can independently design engineering education modules applying the five phases of the ADDIE model and verify inter-modular connectivity through the scientific inquiry method (hypothesis setting→experiment→analysis→conclusion).

Learners can develop three or more module-specific learning scenarios in simulation/VR environments and optimize educational effectiveness through independent/dependent variable control and experimental design.

During a 2–4 week mid-term course, learners can establish a project plan linking three or more modules (e.g., data analysis, system design, prototyping) and pass project-based assessment by scoring 70+ points on predefined evaluation criteria (connectivity 40%, scalability 30%, feasibility 30%). Additionally, they systematically analyze experimental data to derive evidence-based conclusions.
difficulty: Moderate - Standard complexity with some constraints
